did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.repository: Special Collections, University of Virginia Library
did.unittitle: Alfred, Lord Tennyson Letter to Mrs. Joseph Hooker & Photograph, 11 August 1867, n.d.
did.abstract: This collection consists of two items, an undated photograph of Alfred Lord Tennyson, and a letter, dated 11 August 1867, from Lord Tennyson to Mrs. Joseph Hooker.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p:
See the
University of Virginia Library’s use policy.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Alfred, Lord Tennyson, Letter and Photograph, 1867, n.d., #10343-f, Special Collections Department, University of Virginia Library, Charlottesville, Va.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: The Library purchased this letter on July 23, 1993, from Jerry N. Showalter, Bookseller, Ivy, Virginia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of a two page letter, August 11, 1867, from Alfred Lord Tennyson (1809-1892), Farringford, to Mrs. Joseph Hooker, wife of Sir Joseph Dalton Hooker (1817-1911), director of Kew Gardens, in which he states, "Dr. Hooker is far more likely than myself to know whether the C. grandiflorais found in the South Polynesian islands."

Tennyson then directs Mrs. Hooker to a reference to brilliant pink blossoms mentioned in Polynesian researches, during a residence of nearly eight years in the Society and Sandwich Islandsby William Ellis (1794-1872) as a clue concerning the possible identification of the flower. Also present is an undated sepia carte de viste of Tennyson.
